history.content:
Sahai thoughts on AI/ML

@4475

Learning ML

@8510

If you truly self studied 189/231n properly, i.e., you have a good understanding of probability & optimization at the level of 126/127, then the path from here is pretty dependent on what parts you want to tackle. I think systems is a pretty large field and there are a variety of courses that you'd want to talk to a grad student or professor about.

---

As far as systems goes, the AI for systems class has a 162 and 186 prerequisite, so you might find that helpful. 267 is parallel programming, which is necessary for training nets particularly in RL applications. If you want to go even lower level (i.e. TPU level), you might consider 151 or 152.

https://arxiv.org/pdf/1712.05855.pdf <- This paper is also great

children.subject:
<md>Anonymous answerer said "AI for systems class has a 162 and 186 prerequisite," is that correct? Another post mentions 162 and 189 as the prerequisites.
https://piazza.com/class/hyq0br1u3kx7dg?cid=9661</md>

history.content:
I'm a sophomore interested in AI + System and have some (but not very much) background on both sides. What courses should I take? I heard about CS 294-162 and CS 294-159. What's the difference between these two? Are there any other classes?

Now I've taken CS162 and self-studied CS189 and Stanford 231n. Is this background enough to the classes above? I feel that AI + sys is a field with high requirement and don't know where to start...
history.subject: AI + System Courses
